BABY-DROP CENTRES

(Establishment)

     1.  Mr Sin Boon Ann asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports whether the Government will consider adopting legislation to allow for the establishment of "baby-drop centres" to enable mothers with unwanted pregnancies a safe environment for leaving their babies for adoption.

     The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon) (for the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports):   Mr Speaker, Sir, I share the hon. Member Mr Sin Boon Ann's concern for mothers with unwanted pregnancies.  We want to reach out to these mothers and help them make informed, responsible and safe choices.  Our main objective is to ensure that both the baby and mother are safe. 

 

     MCYS has adopted a three-pronged approach to prevent any pregnancy from becoming a crisis. Firstly, sex education is important in preventing unintended pregnancies especially among younger women.  Sex education programme is already part of the school curriculum. MCYS also works with voluntary welfare organisations to conduct talks for teens and workshops for parents on how to guide their children on sex matters.

 

Column: 2248

     Secondly, when a woman has an unwanted pregnancy, we ensure there is relevant social service support to help her make informed choices.  Expectant mothers who are in a dilemma or distress can call the 24-hour National Pregnancy Helpline.  Last month, we also launched the Babes service, which is a collaboration of  seven pregnancy help agencies - Beyond Social Services, KK Women's and Children's Hospital, Tanjong Pagar Family Service Centre, Family Life Society, aLife, Andrew and Grace Home and Rose Villa. 

 

     Thirdly, we work with voluntary welfare organisations to provide a safe environment for the expecting mother to carry the pregnancy to full-term.   If the mother wants to give up her baby for adoption, social workers will help to make the arrangements. In a certain way, these shelters provide the same help to mothers as baby drops.  Last year, through the shelters, 11 babies were successfully adopted and 20 babies were re-united with their natural families. 

 

     We understand the intention of calling for legislation for baby drops.  However, based on overseas experience, legislation has not been effective in preventing babies from being abandoned.  The better approach to take is providing sex education to prevent unwanted pregnancies and assistance to women already in a pregnancy crisis.  Long-term solutions to the problem of abandoned babies require preventive efforts and good support services. 

 

     Often, what is most important to a mother in a pregnancy crisis is the understanding and support of her parents and family. Family members can really make a difference and help the mother make the right decision. The community can also offer a helping hand to any expecting women in distress, and encourage them to seek help early.

     Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, I thank the Minister of State for her reply.  I

Column: 2249

just have a couple of questions.  First, she said earlier that similar legislation overseas which allow for baby drops have not been effective.  Will the Minister of State be able to clarify what she meant by not effective legislation?

 

     My second question essentially relates to social services being readily available and therefore mothers with unwanted pregnancies could go for counselling.  I wonder whether the Minister will agree with me that more can be done in this regard to publicise the kind of help that is available.  We all remember the telephone number for the Pizza delivery service.  But can we recall the number of these help agencies on the top of our head as readily as we do recall the Pizza delivery service?

 

     Finally, although the Government may not be in a position to legislate to allow for baby-drop centres, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Government may be open to such a similar position at some point in time in the future.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the 24-hour National Pregnancy Helpline number is 1800-MUM-TO-BE.  I think it is quite easy to remember than the Pizza number.

 

     Let me thank the Member for his concern.  The reason why legislation overseas has not been effective is that, based on overseas experience, legalised baby-drops have benefits and  problems, but the problems outweigh the benefits.  This includes the misuse of baby-drops to give up babies with sickness, disabled, handicapped and babies who are involved in child trafficking, babies with health risk and whose medical history is unknown, and also legal problems with parental rights if one parent does not know that the baby was given up at a baby-drop.  So if we legalise baby-drops, we risk facing similar problems.  Our current help arrangement is better as it incorporates the benefits of baby-drop and avoid the problems.

 

Column: 2250

     If we make it legal to abandon a baby, even at a baby-drop centre, we are sending a wrong signal that it is acceptable for parents to abandon their responsibility towards their child.  This contradicts the foundation of our child welfare system and promotion of the family as a cornerstone of our society.

 

     Our three-pronged approach - preventive, support services, safe environment and crisis shelter - is better than baby-drops, and it looks after the welfare of both mother and baby.  Baby-drops may save babies but do not care for the mother's health and welfare.  The mother needs proper reproductive healthcare too.  Most mothers who are interviewed have indicated that if their daughter is pregnant and has a baby, they want to know, so that they can support the child.

 

     The spirit of the Children and Young Persons Act which makes abandonment an offence is to protect the safety of children.  The law is still relevant for this reason.  However, we are providing many other avenues for parents who seek help if they have an unwanted pregnancy.  If parents come forward to seek help early, they can be guided to make responsible choices.  They will not be prosecuted for abandoning their baby. Each case is handled as confidential and managed with compassion.

 

     Our approach of using shelters gives us the benefit of the baby-drop and there is no dumping of babies and no prosecution as there is no issue of abandonment.  At the crisis shelter, the mother is given all the help she needs.  Our approach, therefore, gives priority to the safety, health and welfare of both mother and baby.  This is more than what baby-drop provides.

 

     The Member also talked about promotion and also to carry out more activities to help the VWOs to do more in this area.  I totally agree.  I think there is

Column: 2251

still room for improvement.  Definitely, my Ministry, together with the many-helping-hands approach, will do more.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister that with regard to promoting awareness of such crisis centres, particularly to teenagers in secondary schools and beyond, are there programmes to inform the secondary school students, especially of the availability of such centres and to counsel them.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Sir, I mentioned just now that sex education is already part of the school curriculum.  Also, last year, we launched the National Pregnancy Helpline 1800-MUM-TO-BE.  Last month, we also launched the Babes service with seven welfare agencies, like the Tanjong Pagar Family Service Centre, Beyond Social Services, Rose Villa and so on.  I think they also get support from the SMRT for placing posters and brochures.  Maybe if MPs and grassroots organisations want to help us to disseminate the information, we will also give more information to the ground.  For instance, the Nominated MP, Miss Olsen, is also one of the spokeswomen for teenage pregnancy.  I also welcome our MPs to give a helping hand.

     Mr Sin Boon Ann:  Sir, apart from sex education in schools, I would like to know whether teachers are trained to identify and keep a look out for school girls who may be pregnant, and teachers could basically provide early intervention.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Sir, maybe the hon. Member could address this question to MOE.  Anyway, MCYS also works very closely with MOE and MOH.  We will try our best to take Mr Sin's advice to do more on the prevention aspect and also to help teenagers who are pregnant.  So the informed choices are also very important.  I would like to thank Mr Sin for his

Column: 2252

suggestion.  We will definitely work with the other Ministries on this.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to suggest to the Minister of a more coordinated approach to increasing the awareness of the community as well as our young regarding such help as well as regarding the crisis centre and all that are available, because there have been a number of babies that have been dumped into rubbish chutes.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I said that we will definitely need to do more.  But just to put the situation in a proper perspective, from the year 2000 to 2004, on the average, it was about five a year.  Of course, I am not saying that the number is not big - every child's life is important.  But actually in Singapore, it is quite stable and it is a controllable situation.  However, we will still do our best and to take her suggestion of having an inter-Ministry approach.

A NEW OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH FRAMEWORK

(Statement by the Minister for Manpower)

          

     Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has been concerned about workplace safety for some time.  Through various measures, we have reduced the number of accidents and deaths at workplaces over the past 10 years.  But, recently, safety standards have stagnated.  While our present record is better than Asian countries and regions like Hong Kong, Taiwan and Malaysia, we still rank below Japan  and most EU15 countries.   There is much room for improvement, especially at construction sites.

 

     Last year, three serious workplace accidents occurred at Nicoll Highway, the Fusionpolis complex and Keppel Shipyard.  We lost 13 lives there.  Only 2 1/2 months into this year, and we already have 12 fatalities from workplace mishaps.  As

Column: 2253

Singapore becomes more densely populated with  buildings and people, accidents will cause even more damage to life and property.  We must take decisive actions now to avert future mishaps by raising safety standards.

 

     To achieve better results, my Ministry undertook a thorough review of our safety systems, which included a study tour to four European countries - Sweden, the United Kingdom, France and Germany.  Sweden and the UK are the top two safest places to work. In these developed countries, the thinking on occupational safety and health and how to make workplaces safer has advanced dramatically over the past three decades.  I spoke not only to regulators, but also to leaders in international construction firms, unionists, academics and researchers working in private institutions.

 

     In terms of our development of occupational safety and health systems, we have not kept pace with the most advanced countries.  Our Factories Act

is based on the British Factories Act, but the United Kingdom has since revised their regulatory framework.  These developed countries have been able to significantly reduce accidents and deaths only after they evolved new principles and legislation to cope with changing practices.  They recognise that if we just do more of what we have done in the past, improvements, if any, will only be incremental. 

 

Overhaul framework to accelerate a safety culture

 

     To achieve higher safety standards will require a change of mindsets of all stakeholders to be intolerant of safety lapses.  Accidents can only be prevented if all individuals have embedded deep within them a safety culture. 

 

     Government cannot improve safety standards alone.  We have to involve all stakeholders and adopt new principles to accelerate change.  We need an overhaul

Column: 2254

of our present system to ingrain good safety habits in all individuals at the workplace - from top management to the last worker.

 

     Having looked at other systems and exchanged ideas with experts in those countries with excellent safety records, MOM has formulated a new framework and roadmap to improve the safety culture and achieve a quantum leap in safety standards.  While our ultimate goal must be to have zero fatalities, through this new framework, we aim to first reduce deaths at workplaces by a third in five years, and by half within a decade or sooner.  If we can achieve this, then we would have attained current standards comparable to the top 10 developed countries in safety. 

 

New principles to ingrain safety awareness

 

     Three principles are fundamental to our new framework.  First, we should reduce risks at the source by requiring all stakeholders to minimise or eliminate risks which they create.  Accepting risks presented at the workplace leads to unnecessary loss of life.  Instead, under the new framework, those who create risks must be responsible and held accountable to reduce, or better still, eliminate the risks to prevent accidents.  We will therefore require assessments to identify the source of risks at workplaces, the actions to reduce these risks, and the parties responsible for doing so.
 
     These responsibilities will involve persons along the whole process chain including top management.  As examples, architects and engineers must ensure that their construction projects are safe to build and maintain.  Manufacturers and suppliers must ensure that the machinery they supply or maintain is safe to use.  Workers have a responsibility to adopt safe work practices.  In other words, all persons at work must accept responsibility for their own safety, the safety of

Column: 2255

those under their charge, and those they affect through their work. 

 

     The second principle is that industry itself must be required to take greater ownership of safety outcomes.  They must self-regulate to reduce the loss of life and injury to workers under their charge.  Our current Factories Act is prescriptive.  This encourages a mindset among management and workers to follow the “letter of the law�? and not address safety aspects outside prescribed legislation.  Ownership for their workers' safety is lessened as some wait for new regulations before taking action.  But it will be difficult for legislation and enforcement to always keep pace with the rapid technological changes in existing and new industries.
 
     My Ministry, through legislation and enforcement, will continue to maintain standards and set goals for industry to attain our safety targets.  But self-regulation must mean that practitioners who are the most knowledgeable about the hazards that occur in their particular situation must be held responsible to develop safe work procedures.  Each workplace must design and be required to put into place a safety system to adequately respond to specific hazards identified.  These systems must include concrete steps for implementation to put into place safe work practices, machinery and equipment and training of personnel.  Qualified safety professionals will audit these systems for adequacy and compliance.  However, there will still be prescriptive guidance for clearly defined high-risk hazardous sectors and practices. This will be helpful for small and medium enterprises that will need time to adjust to this new framework.

 

     The third principle is that we should prevent accidents through higher penalties for poor safety management.  Safety lapses resulting in mishaps are severely

Column: 2256

punished, but the penalties for offences in the absence of mishaps are comparatively lower.  For example, composition fines are limited to $2,000 per offence.  This encourages the industry to tolerate sub-optimal safety practices until accidents occur.  MOM will impose greater financial disincentives and penalties on workplaces with unsafe systems, before any accident has occurred.
 
Key measures to facilitate change

 

     To effect the new framework, I will, by the end of this year, introduce a new Workplace Safety and Health Act; set up a new Workplace Safety and Health Council; and establish an International Advisory Panel for Occupational Safety and Health.

 

     This new Workplace Safety and Health Act will replace the current Factories Act.  It will articulate the three principles I have outlined earlier into law.  It will specify liabilities for a wider range of stakeholders, strengthen personal accountability of stakeholders and key personnel, and focus more on occupational safety and health goals and systems.  Safety plans will be mandated and safety officers given more responsibilities and powers.  We will table the Act later this year after consulting all stakeholders.

 

     My Ministry will also set up a new Workplace Safety and Health Council to promote self-regulation and instil ownership in safety outcomes.  The Council will involve senior management to oversee sector-specific committees to set standards and drive reforms.  The Council and its committees will comprise experts and representatives from leading companies in safety and health, professional bodies, insurance companies, employer associations, unions, academics, and relevant Government agencies.


     As we catch up with the leading countries, they will also advance in their

Column: 2257

occupational safety and health practices.  We need to keep abreast of international developments to achieve our target of being among the top 10 safest places to work.  I will therefore establish a standing International Advisory Panel to tap expertise and experience beyond our shores.  The Panel will inject fresh and objective views, review and critique our regulatory regime, practices, and standards, and provide international benchmarks.  This will identify our strengths and shortcomings, and enable us to continuously improve our systems and laws.

 

A call to action

 

     The accidents in the Nicoll Highway Collapse, Fusionpolis, and the oil tanker blast at Keppel Shipyard last year serve as stark warnings that we tolerate safety lapses at our own peril.  If the Nicoll Highway Collapse had occurred at the peak of rush hour with many more cars on the road, or led to the collapse of surrounding buildings, the devastation would have been too horrendous to imagine.

 

     These high profile accidents are timely wake-up calls to firm and decisive action.  To achieve better safety standards will require the unstinting support of all stakeholders, including regulators, employers, safety personnel, professional associations, unions, and every individual.  We will consult all stakeholders as to how we can implement this new framework effectively to quickly achieve our goals.  If we are determined in our collective efforts, we can make Singapore, our home, a safer place to work.

     Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, workers who have to work to earn a living here have a right to safe workplaces.  As a labour MP, I would like to stress the point that the employer is the one who is responsible to make sure that the working environment is safe for all workers.  Employers must be aware of

Column: 2258

where the hazards are and take all necessary actions and measures in the work process to achieve a working environment that is safe for our workers.  It is not about putting in place a system or just some kind of procedures or to appoint a safety officer.  Shortcuts should not be taken at the expense of safety.

 

     I would like to ask the Minister, besides the big stick, ie, penalty, how would MOM ensure that employers will do the necessary.  And I would also like to ask the Minister, in introducing a new occupational safety and health framework, whether MOM will also review the safety training framework.  Look at the last few accidents that happened.  Although these areas already have mandatory safety training, accidents still happened. 

 

     It is important to understand that having knowledgeable employees is an integral part of making ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Yeo, no speeches, please.  Ask your questions.

     Mr Yeo Guat Kwang: Yes.  Besides empowering the workers, a mindset change of the enforcement agencies is also necessary.  What will MOM do in this area?

 

     Last, but not least, I would also want to ask the Minister whether he would assure us that the review would not merely be a procedural one or a procedure acting exercise which will end up in unnecessary cost for all.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen: Let me thank the hon. Member for his questions.  I know that Mr Yeo has been at the helm of pushing for a safety review, and for good reason.  Yes, I agree that employers need to hoist this in, and that is why this framework squarely puts in place the responsibility to evolve safety plans to show that they have concrete steps to put these plans into action

Column: 2259

and that they have provided for materials to be bought, for equipment to be provided, to have trained their personnel.  That is the gist of this new framework.

 

     Is this a paper exercise?  This is the crux of the question that Mr Yeo asked.  If anybody thinks that this is a paper exercise, I would advise them to think through this, because this will be enacted into law - harsher penalties for those who do not meet the mark, more rigorous standards and achievements.  But the big stick, as Mr Yeo has pointed out, has been applied before.  So I think the second element, which I have talked about, is to instil ownership, and this is where the Workplace Safety and Health Council plays an integral part. 

 

     This will take us some time to implement, but we should do this together.  We will work with our stakeholders to make sure that this framework delivers the targets that I have set.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister three questions.  I fully agree and support the move to make stakeholders involved at workplace, to be responsible for safety standards and also to imbue in all of them a safety culture.  But I would like to ask the Minister: why does MOM put such a long timeframe of 10 years to reduce our current worksite fatality rate of 4.9 by half, to match the safety standards achieved by the top 10 developed countries?  As every fatality is one fatality too many, should we not have a more aggressive target?

 

     Secondly, how does the Ministry see this new approach that places responsibility for safety on all stakeholders in the operation - from the directors, top management, supervisors, right down to the site workers - impacting on business cost?  Should the Ministry also not consider, as a supplement to the harsher penalties for offences or breach of safety

Column: 2260

guidelines, incentives such as plus points to contractors who maintain high safety standards, ie, instead of just administering the big stick, also put the carrot in?

     Dr Ng Eng Hen: Why 10 years to halve the rate?  It is an important question.  I fully agree with the Member that one fatality is one too many.  But in setting targets, it is important for us to be realistic.  The European countries took about 20 to 30 years to reach their current level.  As I will explain later during the Committee of Supply, we have reached a stage where you require every individual to participate.  I will provide some examples of previous accidents that had occurred.  It will take about two years for this framework and message to reach down to the lowest level.  If we can do it faster, I will be the first one to cheer and be glad.  It took us about 10 years to halve our fatalities to reach this new base,

as provided in the figures.  We have achieved good safety standards and, in Asia, apart from Japan, our safety standards are the next best.  But looking at the experience of other countries, it would take this amount of time for us to reach to the last level before workers can internalise the safety culture.

 

     Do I hope that we can do it faster?  Of course.  And if we can aim for zero fatalities, all the better.  But I want to set realistic targets and milepost so that we can gauge our efforts.  If we find that, within this framework, we are achieving our goals, I think it would be a good problem if we can accelerate our targets.

 

     How do we put in incentives for our sake?  Indeed, incentives already exist.  For example, under BCA or HDB's planning tender contracts, or LTA's contracts, they do put in place incentive systems where someone shows a good safety record, particular incentives are given.  I agree that more needs to be done there and we will look into ways that we can incentivise that. 

 

Column: 2261

     I think one key area is for the Workplace Safety and Health Council to put out information into the market about the good as well as those with not so good safety records.  In terms of business costs, I take it this would impact companies who have not taken time to build up the safety systems.  And indeed, that is the right thing to do.  Those who invested time and effort and resources into building up their safety practices need not fear that this will increase costs disproportionately.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for announcing and putting forth this framework.  As my colleagues Mr Yeo and Dr Khor said, the key is how to filter it down to operation and action.      As a result, our school leavers this year have found jobs soon after graduation and starting salaries have been maintained. Many of you would have read this.  Last year, 91% of our polytechnic graduates found employment within six months of completing their examinations.  Their average monthly starting salary for full-time permanent employment was about $1,620.  This has been maintained.  Our ITE students fared extremely well. 84% found employment within three months of completing their examinations, and had an average monthly starting salary of $1,200.  Graduates from our universities are also getting employed faster.  About 90% of NUS and NTU graduates have already found jobs, with starting salaries of about $2,370 for NUS and $2,500 for NTU graduates.  As for SMU, it reported that its entire first

Column: 2301

graduating cohort (100%) had found work.  So the improved labour market has filtered down to employment opportunities and the numbers are real.  It has not been a jobless recovery.  Singaporeans have benefited.

 

     These positive results, even in difficult years, tell us that our labour policies have been flexible enough to adapt to economic challenges. But it is never a perfect formula.  As Mr Seng Han Thong says, whatever you do, you are going to make somebody less happy.  And, indeed, it is the nature of the game.  Because from time to time, we will have to adjust the levies and quotas to maintain this fine balance, and it is a very fine balance of access to foreign workers and maintaining jobs for Singaporeans.

 

      Some MPs have voiced opposite camps, as I expect.  In fact, I would be worried if too much in one camp was happy.  That tells me that there is imbalance.  Whenever I change, I hope both sides would be equally happy or unhappy.  That will tell me that the balance has been achieved.  Some MPs have voiced concerns during the Budget Debate about the announced levy increases - Dr Wang Kai Yuen, Dr Ahmad Magad, Dr Teo Ho Pin, Mr Lawrence Leow, Mr Chiam See Tong and Mdm Ho Geok Choo who just spoke during her COS cut - fearing that this will dampen our economic recovery.  Others have said that it is too much of a liberalisation.

 

     Sir, I want to assure this House that the increase is justified and will not affect our recovery.  I really do not want to get into a debate about whether our foreign workers add or subtract.  The foreign worker levy and quotas are meant to regulate numbers.  It is a macro economic tool.  And following the footsteps of the Minister for Health, I try not to micro manage as well.  We are macro managers.  In 2004, the stock of work permit holders increased by slightly above 4% whereas local workers increased by just below 3%.  

Column: 2302

In short, we have more foreign work permit holders and it is  growing faster than local workers.  You can say that at the individual level, economy is patchy and recovery is patchy.  But at the aggregated level, there is more demand, which means that as the rate of growth of work permit holders has been growing faster than local workers, it is timely to restore the foreign worker levy.  This will promote the productive use of work permits.  Otherwise, the total number will rise disproportionately as employers bring in more foreign workers than they need.  Local wages, as Mdm Ho Geok Choo rightly pointed out, will be affected.  If you have greater access because they are cheaper, it must drive down all wages.

 

     But the increase will be graduated, as we announced, from $50 to $80 on 1st July 2005, and, subsequently, to $100 on 1st January 2006, to allow time for companies to adjust.  I would like to remind Members, who have quickly forgotten, that this increase is a partial restoration to previous levels.  The skilled levy rate was $200 in 1996.  This rate was reduced substantially in 1998, again in 1999, to help companies tide over the economic downturn.  But our economy grew by over 8% last year.  And this new total levy that companies have to pay after the increase remains a small percentage of overall business operating costs.

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo suggested that we should not impose the levy on certain sectors.  As I said, this is a macro economic tool.  It is not for Government to decide which sector should benefit.  All sectors, I am sure, and indeed all companies, can justify that they needed more than company B, and therefore we should help them.  It is difficult.  We have other schemes to try to help, but it is certainly not through the levy.  I understand her passion for the aerospace industry, as she calls it the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) industry, and I recognise their problems.  We will work with them

Column: 2303

to ensure that there is a steady pipeline of local workers who can fill these jobs.  Because these industries are growth industries, and she is quite right, it is important to our GDP.  But it also represents a very viable career choice, a long-term career choice for Singaporeans.  It is high-tech, high value, high earning, high skills, that all these four attributes spelt to me - Singaporean, Singaporean, Singaporean, Singaporean.  So when we started the industry and we did not have workers to do this, we allowed these companies to bring in foreign workers.  Some companies brought in as many as 90% foreign workers.  It was a special dispensation to be given for a specific time.  But as in most things, what is given is considered an entitlement, and when you want to claw it back, albeit at a very snail pace, there is much noise. We started training polytechnic graduates for this industry many years ago.  And I am happy to report that those graduates will be graduating soon.  I think the first batch is graduating this year.  I accept that it will take an even longer time to help them have the experience.  But we must start so that it represents viable opportunity choices for Singaporeans.  Yes, we will work with her.  She mentioned the partnership scheme, where EDB, WDA, the industries and professional organisations work together.  But let us see how we can make this a viable career choice for Singaporeans. 

 

     Let me also elaborate on the changes which the Prime Minister had announced in his Budget Statement: in allowing companies to hire workers beyond the current dependency ceiling.  Some MPs have asked for clarification on this higher levy of $500, which Mr Seng Han Thong has also brought up.

 

     Sir, I want to explain to Members and the public that this specific change of $500 is not to allow, at a broader scale,

Column: 2304

all companies more foreign workers.  The operative words  are  "all companies", "more foreign workers".  It is really to allow those companies who have reached their current ceiling, what we call the dependency ceiling (DC), to respond to surges in demand.  We are not liberalising our foreign worker policy.  As I said, it works well.  We will maintain that fine balance.  We are upping the levy and that is on a broader scale.  But for specific companies that need more workers than anticipated, under the old scheme, what happened?  Under the old scheme, we set, let us say, for manufacturing, a dependency ceiling of 50%; in other words, if you have 50 local workers, you can hire 50 foreign workers, (50:50).  If you reach that limit and suddenly your business is good - nobody has predicted that the electronics sector does well - you apply for more foreign workers because it is hard to get local workers or for whatever the reason, under the old scheme we say "no".  You can remonstrate, jump up and down, we just say "no".  Or we say "yes", but it would be after a laborious process where the company would lobby many agencies, justify with thick letters why they need it; how they are important to the GDP, which we agree; and how it would bring more jobs to the locals, which we agree.  But it would be a very reluctant "yes", because we knew once we said "yes" to one company, others could equally justify their needs.  It wasted a lot of time, not only of the parties involved, but also of the companies and economic agencies.  So I do not think it is a good system. Even after that laborious process, few companies were allowed to hire foreign workers beyond the DC.  So they just could not meet business demand. 

 

    So instead of this cumbersome system, MOM has decided to use the $500 levy to control the use beyond our current DC.  In other words, there is no need to justify.  I will just set it at a higher price.  If you really need it, then I will give

Column: 2305

it to you, but you pay this higher price.  In other words, companies that really need it will pay and use it because the demand may be temporary.  But this increase is not unlimited.  From 1st July, the new dependency ceiling (DC) will go up to 60% for manufacturing companies, which is now 50%.  The DC for services companies will go up to 40%, which is now 30%.

 

     In essence, there will be a new higher tier above the existing DC. If you are not already confused, I will confuse you even more later.  But let me try to explain to Members simply.  Companies which have not reached the current dependency ceiling, whether they are in the manufacturing or services sector,  will not be affected by this $500 levy.  In other words, they will just be subjected to the new $80 or $100 skilled levy.  Currently, some 93% of manufacturing companies and 75% of service companies who hire work permit holders are operating under their DC.  In other words, even if you say 50% for manufacturing companies and 30% for service companies, they hire workers way below their DC.  So the $500 levy will not affect them at all. They still have some capacity and they only pay the new levy, whether it is $80 or $100, which the chart shows.  The higher levy only affects the remaining companies that are operating currently at their DC and wish to take on more work permit holders.  So if you want to go beyond, as the chart shows, for those extra, you pay $500. Some businesses say, "Well, 50-60% or 30-40%, this is a very small increase.  You load a high levy and yet you don't give us increase in capacity."  This is where I have to explain patiently using Singapore new Mathematics.  You know that we are No. 1 in the world, and I come from the Ministry of Education, so I will explain it to you.

     A 10% increase in DC actually translates to a potential increase of 50% in foreign workers.  I will give you some time to absorb that.  This is new Mathematics. 

Column: 2306

If you look at the chart, the DC reflects the number of foreign work permit holders that a company can hire as a percentage of its total workforce.  So, if the DC now is 50%, you can hire 50 foreign workers for 50 local workers.  When you say it is 60%, you can actually hire 75 work permit holders, the lower bar, because your workforce is now 125.  If you do your Mathematics, 75 divided by 125 is 60%.  It is no sleight of hand, it is true Mathematics.  But I can well understand why if Members say this is quite hard to understand.  And I agree with you that dependency ratios are actually easier, which means that manufacturing companies now with a DC of 50%, the dependency ratio is one to one, ie, you can hire one foreign worker for one local worker.  When we change it to 60%, it is 1.5 to 1, a 50% increase.  Henceforth, we will change the dependency ratios, because we really do not need to be exercising our minds about ratios and then have to do extrapolations.  It will give us a clearer picture. 

 

     But as I said, the raised skilled levy to $100 is to control the numbers; $500 is to give the flexibility.  We are doing this because business cycles have become less predictable.  Companies need greater flexibility to take advantage of new opportunities quickly.  Ensuring that employers get the skilled manpower that they need - which is the point that Mr Seng Han Thong made - will, in turn, help create more jobs for Singaporeans over time when businesses grow.  Is the $500 levy cast in stone?  No.  As the PM mentioned, it is to control numbers.  We will watch what happens.  If too many people use it and our foreign worker population grows rapidly, we will increase it.  If we find that nobody uses it, then it is a wrong figure and we may have to reduce.  

 

     The raised DC only affects the manufacturing and services sectors.  The marine industry is not affected because it already has a higher dependency ratio.  It can hire three foreign workers for every one local

Column: 2307

worker it employs.  For construction, the dependency ratio is 1:4.  They can hire four foreign workers for every one local worker they hire.  But for construction, the main limitation has been the man-year entitlement (MYE) system, which Mdm Cynthia Phua talked about in the Budget debate.  She said it was too restrictive and rigid, and we are making it too difficult.  You set a quota and companies cannot respond.  I agree with her.  I have therefore decided to loosen controls to allow the construction industry better use of their manpower resource.

 

     Currently, contractors need to produce MYEs when they renew the work permits of their existing workers or when they take over workers from other contractors, even if these workers have existing work permits.  With effect from 1st April 2005: 


     (1)  Contractors will no longer need MYEs when they renew the work permits of foreign workers who have worked with them for six or more years.  In other words, the MYE system will be lifted for this particular group of skilled workers who have worked for them for six years or more.  They do not require MYEs.  The renewal will be capped at one year at a time, and restricted to those involved in on-going projects.  The reason is that this will help the industry to retain a core group of experienced and skilled workers, which would also contribute to better safety in the construction sector.  A trained worker is a safer worker.  Going one step further, in line with this philosophy, MOM will also no longer allow the employment of unskilled foreign workers in the construction sector, with effect from 1st December 2005.  The impact on the sector will be very small, since the vast majority of the construction workers now, ie, 97%, are already skilled.  So, we are just saying, it is only 3%, you do not need the unskilled workers, let them all be skilled.

     (2)  We will also allow contractors to take on transferred workers - which we did not allow before - ie, change employers for the remaining validity period of the work permits.  When they take on these transferred workers, no new MYEs will be required from the employer receiving the workers under the transfer.


     (3)  We will allow contractors to temporarily "loan" their foreign workers to other contractors during lull periods, that is, there is no change of employer in this case, they can work for another employer.  Workers must consent to this arrangement and be paid accordingly, and must be involved only in construction work. Their official employer remains responsible for their management, housing, salary, well-being and levy.  In other words, we will allow this only if the worker agrees.  The idea is, once you are in the system and you want to work for another employer because this employer has a lull in his business, we should allow it; and

 

     (4)  Contractors can use up all the MYEs allocated to them for a project as long as the construction project is still on-going.  Previously, MYEs expired three months before the end of the project.  This will no longer be the case.

 

     I am well aware that reducing upfront these rules to allow industries to utilise manpower more efficiently is the right thing to do. But there are concerns about the potential abuse of the system.  These changes are to allow optimal use of manpower.  I think it will benefit us all.  There probably will be no disagreement on this.  But I would like to caution those who abuse these relaxations and illegally deploy construction foreign workers into other sectors.  In line with these changes, my Ministry will double the size of our enforcement team from about 70 officers to about 130 in the coming financial year.  MOM will intensify its enforcement efforts to police deployment of construction

Column: 2309

workers outside the sector and contractors who violate the law will be taken to task.

 

     Let me categorically say we will not hesitate to punish errant contractors.  Current penalties, I would like to remind everyone, include a lifetime ban from employing foreign workers - what it means is that you might as well give up the industry if you are in it - fines and jail sentences.  I also want to urge contractors that the well-being of foreign workers needs to be ensured.  Salaries must be paid on time, and their well-being looked after.  In tandem, MOM will educate construction foreign workers on their rights and act on complaints.  We will increase their accessibility to tell them which numbers they can call and, as I said, let me reiterate, we will not hesitate to punish contractors who abuse their workers.  


     Sir, I like now to move on to medium and long-term challenges which Members have brought up.  While our present policies have helped us ride through these difficult years, we need to prepare now to face future challenges.  Members have asked for projections.  Prof. Koo Tsai Kee asked what is the long-term and medium-term outlook like. 

 

     Even after taking into account the unemployment peak in 2003 due to SARS, we still averaged about 3.4% over the period 1997-2003 - those were difficult times - lower than other developed or developing countries.  If you look at the chart - compared to other developed countries - Taiwan, at 3.7%, is higher than us; even in this difficult period, USA, UK, Hong Kong.  I would like to remind Members that the specific circumstances which hit Singapore and Singapore only and spared the other countries, and even in that context, Singapore did fairly well in comparison.  Over time, as our economy experiences technology-driven productivity improvements, and shifts to higher

Column: 2310

value-add activities, we will require fewer but more skilled workers.  It is the nature of our industries.  Other developed and developing economies have also faced the same situation.  Japan has posted negative employment growth since 1993, ie, 12 years of negative employment growth.  Similarly, whilst Korea, Taiwan, Australia and Hong Kong enjoyed a slight rebound in employment in recent years, their overall employment growth trend since 1991 has been negative. 

 

     Like other developed countries, fewer jobs will be created for the same level of GDP growth.  Let me explain to you and give you numbers to illustrate.  When we last had 8.0% growth in 1995, and about 8.2% in 1996, that growth created some 109,000 and 103,000 jobs respectively.  Last year, as Members will remember, when we had 8% growth, our economy created 66,000 jobs, ie, fewer jobs created per percentage growth, but higher value, higher skill added.  We are unlikely - and this is not the forecast that we will grow 8% every year, because we are developed - with slower growth, and lower rates of job creation, to see unemployment fall back to the 2% levels of the early 1990s.

 

     For 2005, our economic growth rate is expected to be within the 3-5% range, well below the 8% experienced last year.  So, job growth this year might not be as strong as last year, and unemployment will remain at about 3.5-4.0%.  Even at these levels, I want to remind Members, our unemployment rates remain lower than most other countries.

 

     Looking ahead, our workforce faces the challenge of increased globalisation.  To continue to grow, Prof. Koo Tsai Kee asked what tricks do we have up our sleeves.  I wish I was a magician.  But we stick to fundamentals.  We must maintain our cost competitiveness.  Over the past 10 years, I want to report to Members of this House that our cumulative increases

Column: 2311

in wages have outstripped our productivity. 

 

     Even during the recessionary years after the Asian crisis and during the dot-com bust and September 11 - in other words, when the economy went down - our wages did not fall, as the chart indicates.  That orange line has always been above productivity.  Only now is the cumulative increase in productivity “catching up�? with the increase in real wages.  The adjustments were made because of reductions in CPF and wage restructuring.  So, it was the right thing to do.  When the economy was difficult, we took decisive steps and it has made the difference.  Now, as you can see, these cost-cutting measures have worked - the blue line is above the orange - and we have brought our wage costs in line with productivity growth.  But the Government cannot keep on reducing CPF, without adversely affecting the retirement security of Singaporeans.  Even as our economy improves, we must ensure that our wages do not again move at a faster pace than our productivity increases.  Companies must also continue with wage restructuring so that our wages can respond more flexibly to changes in market conditions. 

 

     Sir, I am optimistic that so long as our tripartite partnership is strong and we collectively take adequate measures to face our challenges ahead, our economy will grow and jobs will be created.  We are in a far better position than countries which have chosen to be protectionist and, as a result, have fallen far behind.  Even these countries have had to adjust.  Members would have read how some countries with traditionally confrontational labour relations have come to realise that it is unsustainable.  The government of the eastern German town of Leipzig persuaded BMW to locate there instead of the neighbouring Czech Republic, and managed to take nearly 500 unemployed

Column: 2312

persons off the dole and onto BMW's assembly line.  How could they do it?  The unions played a great part by agreeing to longer working hours during peak phases and to cut hours when demand is low.  This would have been unheard of years ago - flexi-time in a predominantly German socialist tradition.  This shows what can be accomplished when companies and unions work with the government to turn things around.  And we have already moved far ahead.  So, we are in a good position.

 

      Sir, we cannot shield ourselves or Singaporeans from changes, but we can prepare them to adapt.  I share the concerns that Members raised during the Budget debate, eg, Dr Ong Seh Hong, Mayor Teo Ho Pin, that we need to look at skills, security and jobs.  MOM and WDA will do more to help Singaporeans know where the job opportunities are.  That is one area where we should give more information.  We should give assessments of the employment outlook.  We currently have vacancies in jobs such as finance and administrative managers, electronics engineers, IT personnel, aerospace technicians, sales representatives, customer service personnel, sales and service workers, security guards, and a host of other occupations.  The public sector has another 3,100 job openings for teachers, management executives and for the uniformed services.  But it gets very complex.  So, what I have told staff to do is: can you improve this communication effort so that the information is packaged into useful, actionable and digestible bite-sized nuggets for specific sectors, targeted so that people know and say, "OK, this is what I want to plan for in the next few years"?

 

     Looking ahead, the services sector will continue to create a substantial number of jobs.  In the manufacturing sector, most of the growth will be in areas such as biomedical sciences and petrochemical industries.  Employment in the electronics

Column: 2313

cluster is expected to remain stable, with new jobs created in the higher-end semiconductor and wafer fabrication balancing jobs lost

in other areas.  On the whole, we expect to see employment in the sector changing its mix towards more skilled manpower.

     What about business outsourcing?  Despite the immense competition posed by China and India, we were still ranked the fourth most desirable location for business process outsourcing (BPO) by AT Kearney last year.  In another recent study by the Economist Intelligence Unit, Singapore ranked as the top location for outsourcing, with 22.6 projects per million people, well ahead of China and India, and other countries like Ireland, Netherlands and Hong Kong.

 

    While the world comes to Singapore for business process outsourcing, Singapore is also going to the world, like other small countries such as Switzerland, Denmark and Sweden.  We will need people with international skills and capabilities to fill these jobs whose companies must find external markets to survive.  Maersk, for example, the Danish shipping company, sends its people wherever it sends its ships.  Likewise, so does PSA and SIA, to operate their international port and air networks.  My Ministry will work with other agencies to internationalise Singaporeans' mindset and prepare them for these opportunities.

 

     I agree with Mr Alex Chan and Mr Yeo Guat Kwang that Singaporeans will need to have new skill sets.  Mr Chan will recall his involvement in the ERC where we strongly recommended a champion agency for this task.  This was indeed the reason that WDA was set up. 

 

     The WDA recently launched the employability skills system (ESS) to help all workers at all levels, including executives and managers which some Members have

Column: 2314

asked for, to enhance their foundational or soft skills, which Mr Seng Han Thong talked about.  WDA will push ahead with workforce upgrading in specific industry sectors to raise skills competitiveness and to support Singapore's restructuring to higher value-added activities.  We will also work with SMEs to step up workforce development. 

 

     These CET programmes give our workers opportunities to upgrade and enhance their employability.  Some Members have talked about older workers, whether they have adequate access.  This is a particular area that we are looking at.  I agree with Mr Yeo Guat Kwang and Mr Ahmad Khalis during the debate on the Budget Statement that we should reduce barriers as much as possible.  Some of these barriers have been mentioned by Mr Low Thia Khiang.  I agree with him that as far as possible, we cannot use paper qualifications.  If I ask him, "Do you have an "O" level certificate?" - where he did not have that opportunity - and you say, "You need this certificate before you can upgrade."  It is a Catch-22 position.  He needs that paper certificate so that he can upgrade.  That is why we have only required minimal formal entry criteria for our programmes.  So be rest assured that the lower skilled who have not completed formal education before can benefit.

 

     Our idea is not to keep people out.  The key point, as Members have pointed out, including Mr Low Thia Khiang, is that it must translate to more employability, better pay, more value for the job.  That is the key.  If you can demonstrate that, then I do not care what you have done before.  I want to start with a new slate, and push on. 

 

    On developing other areas like entrepreneurship, WDA will build on its efforts to help job-seekers take up self-employment in retail businesses.  Members have asked for a report on how we are doing.  If you ask me how WDA, in

Column: 2315

partnership with many of our Distributed CareerLink Network partners - NTUC, the CDCs - is doing, I would say that we are much better than we were two years ago.  There is room for improvement but our capabilities have improved.  More importantly, we have managed to segment the population.  We may have started a bit naively, in that we assume that as long as you got training, you were better off.  So we trained thousands upon thousands.  We would have been indeed naive to say that if you failed in one job training - in other words, you trained in one course and it did not lead you to another job,  I should train you in another course - we would train you in multiple courses and allow you to fail multiple times.  So triage is important; customised effort, what does this person need?  Some basically just need a pat on the shoulder and you say, "Charge on, you will get a job", and it works.  It will cost you less and it will work.  Some really need hand-holding.

 

    Members would have heard of the enormous efforts Mayor Matthias Yao had to do.  Not only did he have to find them job training, find them work, he had to hire a bus to bring these workers to the workplace.  Is he overly sympathetic?  No, he is realistic.  His officers told him that they tried before but these people did not even go to their workplaces.  They got lost taking the bus.  Others have said that if they can get lost in Singapore, using the public service, then maybe they should not get the job.  But his officers realised that they need to deal with the problem.

 

    I would say that we have increased our capabilities.  But let me give Members some statistics.  We have helped place more than 27,000 Singaporean job-seekers into jobs through our Distributed CareerLink Network (DCN) partners, of whom 17,600 were lower-skilled workers with secondary education or below, and 15,000 of these workers were above 40

Column: 2316

years old.  I think we are helping the right group. 

 

    Under our Place and Train programmes, we move away from training for training's sake.  I want to find you a job, then I train you.  Under our Place and Train programmes, WDA has placed some 1,800 unemployed Singaporeans in new jobs, of whom 45% of these workers are above 40 years old.  It is not that we are targeting the easiest group. We can actually target the easiest group to report to you good results.  But we are targeting the ones who need it most and where we find that they will benefit more.  For example, we have a programme called TextiLE, where we are working with Mr Yeo Guat Kwang, that will benefit older and lower-skilled workers.  Some 124 unemployed Singaporeans have been placed and trained at the start of this programme.  From this programme, we know that older Singaporeans can be seamstresses and have a steady job in this career.  In this programme, about 68% of workers were aged 40 years and above, and 95% were lower skilled.  Another 1,400 unemployed Singaporeans have been retrained and placed into jobs in sectors such as healthcare, under the Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme and other retraining programmes.  These are mid-career ones, eg, executives, technicians, professionals, etc.

 

   We will also help those employed workers upgrade their skills.  The SDF did support some 600,000 training places of which 36% went to older workers and 28% went to lower skilled workers, with less than "O" level qualifications.  In particular, the Skills Redevelopment Programme, jointly promoted by NTUC and WDA, supported some 37,000 places in 2004. Again, 60% went to those above 40 years old and 61% went to lower skilled workers with less than "O" level qualifications.  I take that we are targeting the right population.  Can we do more?  Yes.  Can we improve?  Definitely.  We

Column: 2317

need to build capability with our partners.  Previously, we never needed this capability when we had a 2% unemployment rate.  It was just frictional unemployment.  We had more jobs than job seekers.  What we have done with our partners is to say that we will fund them over a longer term, and build up the capability of their individual officers. 

 

    Mr Ahmad Khalis asked during the Budget debate whether there are barriers, echoed by Mr Low Thia Khiang in this COS.  We recognise that they need to be customised.  We need to improve access.  We will customise our training programmes into bite-sized models, and we will facilitate access and shorten training duration.  In other words, we actively want to overcome the hurdles that others face. 

 

   But these schemes and programmes are not just about statistics.  They are about real people, and knowing how we can make a big difference in the lives of fellow Singaporeans will spur us on.  Let me just give you two examples.  Ms Cheong Leng Sin, 50 years old, a former bank supervisor, had been with the company for 23 years before she was retrenched in 2003.  A very faithful worker, she stayed with the company for 23 years.  Undeterred after her retrenchment, she decided to explore new job opportunities.  Subsequently, she attended the NTUC/WDA STEER programme and took up a Nursing Assistance course.  Leng Sin's performance during the Nursing Assistance course impressed the National Heart Centre so much that they offered her a scholarship for a full-time nursing course.  She now earns less than what she did before, but derives immense job satisfaction in her new career as she is able to reach out and help patients at the Centre.

 

     Another example is Mr Lum Hon Cheong.  He worked in a shipyard for almost 13 years before he was retrenched last May.  He decided to sign up for the

Column: 2318

Trainee Charge-Hand (TRAC) Scheme which places retrenched or unemployed Singaporeans into shipyard jobs as trainee charge-hands or supervisors.  He has been working with Jurong Shipyard for the past four months.  He had to take a $600 pay cut and bear his own transportation costs.  But he is now undergoing a string of certifiable upgrading training sponsored by the company and he can be assured of a promotion to project supervisor if he performs well.  On completion of the traineeship, he will be drawing about $1,300 to $1,400 a month.

     Could the Government help to increase the level of financial independence for these vulnerable Singaporeans?  I truly believe we can.  The Ministry could, apart from working closely with WDA and the CDCs to look for employment opportunities, take a leaf from the private-partnership model by actively working with the private sector to create employment opportunities for these people.  I had, in fact, touched on this possibility in my earlier speech on the financial policy of the Government.

     Mr Sin Boon Ann:  Sir, I wish to ask what steps have been taken by the Government in facilitating the employment of the disabled?  I read recently that Victor's Cafe hired three intellectually disabled people as waiters.  This is unusual for the industry.  The cafe owners said that although the intellectually disabled people may look a bit different, "that doesn't mean they can't do the job as well or even better".  This effort is laudable and should be showcased.

adequately address the issue of facilitating the employment of the disabled.

What is also needed is a focus by employers not on their differences, physically or intellectually, but on their common abilities and skills.

dependence on family members or financial assistance, depressed self-esteem and so on.  Hence, I would like to recommend that MCYS work very closely with MND in the planning and revision of public facilities and infrastructure to ensure that all these little kinks are ironed out.  It is also very important that the disabled be given the opportunity to be self-reliant.  Many of them, in fact, are eager to contribute and be active and involve members of our community.

     The Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan): Sir, I would like to share the two key priorities of my Ministry over the next two years.

    

     The first is to build a caring and inclusive society, where no one will be left behind.  As a country, Singapore has made a strategic decision to ride on globalisation, to have an open economy, to run a competitive system, in order for us to tap and harvest every opportunity for economic growth. And we have to do this because we are small and this is the only way to survive.  However, the corollary of this strategic decision is that there will be increased competition for our people - competition which we cannot insulate our people from.  And it is important that Members of this House appreciate this strategic fact. This sense of competing at the highest level is what makes Singapore exciting, but it is also what causes deep-seated anxiety and even fear in the hearts of some people who are worried that they may not be able to keep up with this fast paced competitive society, and are afraid that they will be left behind in this race.  Our job is to make sure that every Singaporean and every family in Singapore has an opportunity to build a better life, to harvest the fruits of our labour as a nation, and an assurance that there will be a helping hand and no one will be left behind.

 

     I agree with the sentiment that we cannot outsource the poor, because we are not a company.  We are a nation and therefore we are in this together.

  

    The second key priority is that we need to nurture the relationships that give us happiness, fulfilment and significance

Column: 2407

to our lives.  At a personal level, my life is worthwhile because of my relationships with my wife, children, friends, colleagues and my fellow citizens.  Family, friends and colleagues give us a reason to live, work and play.  Shared experiences and memories are what bind us together as a society and what root us to this precious place called home.  We derive a sense of ownership, not just from owning a flat but because of the opportunity to contribute, to build and leave something behind in this place called Singapore to make the difference.  And that is why my Ministry focuses on the family, voluntary welfare organisations, racial and religious harmony, volunteerism, philanthropy, sports and opportunities for youth.  Ultimately, it is about relationships, and enhancing the relationships that enrich our lives.  So just bear these two key priorities in mind - that no one is left behind and it is about enriching our relationships.

 

     Let me now focus on the first priority.  Many Members have raised eloquent and deeply-felt pleas on behalf of the poor and needy and have asked how they are faring.  As our economy grows and as we go through this painful restructuring, I know that there are Singaporeans out there who are feeling anxious and who are feeling the burden of this restructuring.

 

     The past seven years from 1998 to 2004 have been difficult for the lowest  20th percentile of our population.  Although the cost of living has not risen by much, wages for the less skilled jobs have declined marginally.  Although at the statistical level, we may say that these are marginal changes, to real people on the ground facing these situations, these fears and anxieties are amplified.  And this is not something that we can wish away - globalisation, recessions, restructuring, terrorism and biological plagues are facts of life. 

 

Column: 2408

     Some workers with only basic education obviously face increased difficulties finding jobs despite their best efforts.  There are older Singaporeans who are frail, sometimes without family support, and sometimes with little savings.  Similarly, while we have some disabled Singaporeans who are gainfully employed, we all know that it is that much more difficult for disabled persons to find jobs.  If a person with no disability already has difficulty finding jobs, it can only be harder for a disabled person.  I want to assure Members - and Mr Sin has asked me for an assurance - that we will not neglect such Singaporeans.  They deserve their fair share of opportunities and they deserve our assistance.

 

     I have distributed a handout enumerating all the current social assistance schemes that exist as of today.  One Member just now toted up and said he had counted nine.  I do not know whether to be pleased or to be disappointed to inform him that there are 51 - probably more as I still have not toted up all - and if Members look at the details in that handout, there are actually quite a lot of assistance available.

 

     We actually have a very robust social safety net in Singapore and one which delivers considerable benefits to our people who need it most.  But what is different, unique perhaps, about our social safety net compared with the welfare state that many Members, especially the Opposition Members, keep harping about is that in Singapore, this assistance is focused.  It is focused specifically at the lowest 20% and it also takes into account the fact that the lowest 20th percentile are not a homogenous group.  They are actually heterogeneous with different circumstances and with different needs.

 

     Having said that, if Members look at what the Government provides for our people, the first tier is what I define as universal subsidies.  By this, I mean healthcare, education and housing.  The last time

Column: 2409

we tried to compute a value for this, this worked out to at least $12,000 a year.  These are the subsidies for healthcare, housing and education.  Over and above this, we have a comprehensive range of assistance schemes which are tailor-made for the different groups in the bottom 20%. The approach we use for each group must be different.

 

     Let me give Members a few examples.

For those who have lost their jobs, we need to provide interim assistance.  We obviously need to help them get re-employed and get back on their feet.  For another group, whose incomes are low and chronically low, what they need is some ongoing financial assistance to supplement those incomes.  In particular - and I am very struck by Mr Zainudin's speech - we need to make sure that their children get a good education because this is the only sure way to ensure that they escape the poverty trap, and that we will get many, many more Zainudins in Parliament and in the upper reaches of our society in the future.  And then, at the lowest end, we have those who are frail elderly, disabled, who really cannot get a job and support themselves even if they wanted to.  For them, and only them, we provide long-term assistance through our public assistance scheme.  But fortunately for us, at this point in time, this is a small group and as of now there are only about 2,700 households receiving public assistance.

 

5.45 pm

 

     Let me cite a few more examples - real examples - so that you get an idea of how our system works in practice.  A family of four approached the South West CDC for assistance a few months ago.  Both parents were not working, the family had problems making ends meet.  The family received about $1,000 in assistance from the CDC.  The father received job search and assistance through the Work Assistance Programme.  The two

Column: 2410

children received school fee subsidies and free textbooks.  The good news in the case of this family is that the father will be returning to work at the end of this month.  And I understand that he and his wife will receive a combined income of about $1,400.  The family see themselves as now having taken that first step towards self-reliance.

 

     Take another example - a divorcee living with her mother and two children.  To make things worse, she has not been able to work because of a traffic accident.  Since the middle of last year, this family has received financial support through the Interim Financial Assistance Scheme and the Rent and Utilities Scheme.  Her older child receives free uniforms and free textbooks.  The younger child is able to go to a childcare centre because of subsidies under the Centre-Based Financial Assistance Scheme for Childcare.  MUIS has also stepped in with some additional financial assistance.  All in, since September last year, she has received about $3,800 in assistance.  And over and above this, she also benefits from HDB's Public Rental Scheme where she pays less than $50 a month for her 2-room rental flat.  And her family's medical expenses are covered by Medifund.

 

     It is very important to understand the significance of Medifund.  Medifund, in effect, means that every single person in Singapore has access to healthcare and, in cases of families like this, they often do not even pay a single cent for their healthcare.  As a person who has worked at the front-end in hospitals, I can assure you there is no problem as far as access to healthcare for the poor in Singapore.  This is something that is in stark contrast to the situation in developed countries, like the United States or even parts of Europe. 

 

     Let me give you another example - an elderly person living alone, a 69-year old childless widow, who has exhausted her savings with no family to turn to.  We put

Column: 2411

her under the Public Assistance Scheme.  But it is not us alone who is looking after her.  The Sunlove Neighbourhood Link provides her with free meals.  She gets food rations from SATS every alternate month, and she gets ang pows from foundations, like the Hong Leong Foundation and Shaw Foundation.  In total, I have been told that she has been receiving about $4,100 a year.  On top of this again, she receives assistance through Medifund and also takes advantage of highly subsidised housing under the Public Rental Scheme.  Yes, she does not have a lot, but she is taken care of. 

 

      To help low-income families avoid the poverty trap, we also have this scheme called Home Ownership Plus Education (HOPE).  This is a special scheme, preventive or perhaps an incentive scheme, to send the message to these households that if they have smaller families they will be able to focus their resources on these precious few children.  They can create a better future for themselves and their children.

 

     I am sure Members of this House are aware that the sum total that is provided through HOPE is $100,000.  This is a significant sum of money for people in that predicament.  As of end January this year, we have 450 families who were signed on to this scheme.  And I can assure Members of this House that I hope many more will benefit and take advantage of this scheme which we offer to them.

 

     Sir, our social safety net ensures that our poor have a roof over their heads, food on the table, access to medical care, a chance to seek gainful employment, ie, to be trained for the next job, and education opportunities for their children.  That is the guarantee, the hope, the option of social mobility to escape the

Column: 2412

poverty trap.  And this is something which, I think, Singaporeans and, indeed, many of us in this House have not truly appreciated the extent and even, dare I say, the generosity of our social assistance package.  In fact, I would put it to you that you will find very few countries, if at all, either capitalist or communist, which have done as well to look after the poor and give the poor hope, a chance to live a meaningful and self-respecting life, with dignity for themselves and hope for their children. 

 

    Our paradigm is assistance; it is not welfare.  The experience of other countries with excessive welfare benefits has taught us that we need to calibrate how we deliver our help.  All of us want to help, but we need to translate those good intentions into practical and sensible schemes on the ground.  We must not douse the desire to get back on the feet and to be self-reliant.  If we do that, we would have fundamentally changed our society, destroyed our ability to compete and survive, going forward.  And this is even more critical now than ever before in this globalised world with competition that we cannot shield anybody from.

 

     So to put it simply, our approach is assistance, not welfare; mutual obligation, not entitlement.  No Singaporean should feel, when he reads the Straits Times tomorrow and sees these 51 schemes, that he has a right to demand every single cent from every single scheme in that handout.  Everyone of us must still feel the need to strive and work harder for a better life for ourselves and for our family. 

 

     Some Members may feel that this is not being very compassionate.  But I ask you to consider the consequences of choosing an easy populist route and just say, "These are the 51 schemes, let us give them all away.".  If we did that - you and I know that there will be many who will not bother to work, much less upgrade their skills - the Government would

Column: 2413

have to raise taxes, both income tax and GST.

 

     But, frankly, that is not the worst of it.  The most dangerous fact of going down the populist route is the fact that you will have a welfare system which is not sustainable.  And this is the crux of the problem which America and Europe are now struggling to resolve.  And you and I know they have not solved it yet and the problem is only going to get worse.  So we need to understand that, yes, we must love our neighbours, but we need to do it in a sensible, practical and sustainable way.  And what we have so far has worked and can work for the future.

 

     So I come back to the three fundamental principles behind our social safety net.  First, to foster self-reliance.  Our social safety net must be a trampoline.  It must have springs so that someone who falls back on it can spring back up again.  It is not meant to be a comfortable, luxury mattress for you to rest for a long term.  Second, the family.  The family must still remain our primary line of support, including both financial and emotional support.  The Government cannot be a surrogate husband, a surrogate father, a surrogate mother or a surrogate brother or sister.  Your family must still be there for you.  Third, our social safety net is not something that is constructed and held up by the Government alone.  We need "Many Helping Hands".  And that is where ordinary citizens, voluntary welfare organisations and grassroots organisations have an absolutely crucial role to play.  My friends, the issue is not money.  It is not that the Government  is being stingy and trying to save money and therefore asking the VWOs to come forward to help.  The truth of the matter is compassion, dedication, sensitivity and passion.  The energy of volunteers is something which cannot be matched by paid employees of the Government dishing out dole.  There is a world of

Column: 2414

difference between a volunteer and a paid person, simply following the book and handing you a cheque every month. 

 

     That is not to say that our current system is perfect.  I will be the first to admit it is not perfect, and that is why we need to continually look at it critically and try to improve it.  So let me now touch briefly on ComCare because my Minister of State will go through the details.  Let me explain the significance of ComCare.  What does it mean to all of us?  First, it means we are setting up a sustainable source of funds for the poor in Singapore.  All of you know that the Ministries are on block budgets.  All of you also applauded when you were told that the Ministries' block budgets were going to be cut.  All of you also then knew that, in tough times, all Ministries, including my Ministry, would have their budget cut.  Consequently, we felt that by setting up an Endowment Fund which will then generate interest, we will be able to have a source of funds which will be available in both good and bad times for our people.  That is why although, as of now, it is going to go up to $500 million, in the long term we need a billion dollars or perhaps even more, so that it will truly be sustainable and, in a sense, budget neutral. 

 

     The second point which I want to emphasise about ComCare is that it signifies our commitment to do more.  We have an ageing population.  We have an economy which is going to be under increased pressure from competition from other parts of the world.  So, yes, I think more people will need assistance in the future.  There will be new money for new programmes.  ComCare for this year will provide $55 million for a start.  This is 40% more than we spent on the current schemes last year.  This is proof that we are putting our money where our mouth is, that we are going to spend more money

where it is needed, not just spend money and dish it out, but do it in a disciplined and sensible way.
