     Third, the establishment of ComCare gives us an opportunity to streamline our schemes.  After I looked at that handout, I found 51 schemes.  It is no wonder none of us, including the people out there, knew what was available for social assistance.  I think this is a wonderful opportunity for us to rationalise and simplify and make it easier for all of us to implement the schemes.  It does not necessarily mean that it is going to be easier for people to get more money.  I do not think that should be the interpretation.  But it means we should have a more rational and simplified interface to assistance.

 

     Fourth, many of you have emphasised the need for flexibility, and I agree with you absolutely.  Every individual and every family in trouble is different.  Yes, for some schemes, we can use strict criteria, eg, whether you are working or not working, how much are you earning, how many people in your family, etc.  But beyond the standard criteria-based schemes, there is a need for flexibility at the edges, and ComCare will provide that additional flexibility at the edge.

 

     The fifth point which is significant about ComCare is that we are now signalling a decentralised approach to the delivery of public assistance.  Why CDCs and why VWOs?  Because they are on the ground and they consist of people who are living next to you, living amongst you, living in the community, people who know whether you are truly in need or whether you are using the money for beer and cigarettes, people who can see you, live with you and feel your pain and share your burdens.  So, I believe the grassroots organisations will bring their local knowledge, their hearts and their human touch into play.  And it will not be an impersonal Ministry up in Thomson Road that is giving you assistance. 

 

Column: 2416

     My Minister of State will elaborate on the details later, but there will basically be three categories of funds under ComCare.  The first one we have called it ComCare Self-Reliance.  That is focused on needy families who need interim assistance to tide over periods of unemployment.  The second one we have called it ComCare Grow, and that is basically focused on children to ensure that children from needy families - and when I say needy families, let me emphasise that it does not matter whether that is a standard nuclear family, broken family, divorced family or children with single parents or children of elderly parents -all children who need help will receive help.  And, in particular, we will look after their educational needs.  The third category we have called it ComCare Enable, which focuses on those who need long-term assistance, eg, the frail elderly living alone and people with disabilities.


     One specific feature which we are going to construct is a central database because, with so many schemes and so many people doing so many things, there is a real danger of either some people taking advantage and applying for more than what they need.  Similarly, there is also a danger of some people falling through the cracks and not receiving the help that they need.  So I believe my Ministry's role will be to act as a central interface for this information to be shared by all our many partners on the ground who are delivering assistance. 

 

     I also agree with the sentiment that many of you have expressed - that we do need more social workers and our social workers need to be more equipped and to have the necessary support to do their work.  I want to acknowledge here that social workers in Singapore play an incredibly important role and, in fact, have been one of the most under-appreciated, under-recognised professions in Singapore, and we must take steps to correct that.

 

Column: 2417

     Let me now move on to ageing issues.  Many Members, such as Mr Davinder Singh, Ms Irene Ng, Dr Lily Neo and Dr Warren Lee, have spoken on these.  Let me first say that I agree with all of you that we need an inter-agency approach.  Ageing issues cut across many sectors, Ministries and agencies, and that is why we do not have a single Ministry for the elderly.  We have instead set up a Committee on Ageing Issues (CAI).  This is chaired by the Senior Minister of State for Health, Dr Balaji Sadasivan, and co-chaired by my Parliamentary Secretary, Dr Mohamad Maliki Osman.  It comprises both Government and VWO representatives, and this committee has been tasked to focus on five priority areas:

 

     (1)  Financial security of the elderly;

 

     (2)  Improving the employability of older Singaporeans;

 

     (3)  Enabling older Singaporeans to live with their families;

 

     (4)  Promoting active ageing; and

 

     (5)  Making sure that there is a continuum of care, both healthcare and social care services which our elderly need.

 

These are not trivial issues.  It is not something which we are going to solve overnight, but I put it to you that we have recognised that these are five big areas which we need to look at and address in a significant way. 


     Mr Ong Ah Heng asked how much we are spending on eldercare and whether this will increase in the future.  MCYS' and MOH's budget for eldercare services in this financial year will work out to a total of $98 million.  It comprises $12 million from MCYS and $86 million from MOH.  This represents an annual growth rate of 4.5% compared to the $82 million that was spent in FY 2001.


Column: 2418

     Much of our expenditure on the elderly goes into the Eldercare Masterplan.  This is where we fund the VWOs to run a range of eldercare services.  It ranges from development programmes for the healthy, all the way to services for the frail.  And we are currently reviewing this range of services and we will develop a new Eldercare Masterplan for FY 2006 to FY 2010.  We will do this in consultation with our service providers and with the users on the ground. 

 

     We will explore Dr Lily Neo's suggestions; Dr Warren Lee's suggestions on seeing how GPs can play a role; and we will certainly look at Dr Chong Weng Chiew's and Ms Irene Ng's suggestion for match-making services for those over 40 and even the elderly and the disabled.  I think love should not have an expiry date.

 

     Mr Wee Siew Kim and Mr Sin Boon Ann talked about creating job opportunities for older Singaporeans.  This is going to be a priority area.  We have just finished the COS for MOM where we talked about reviewing the retirement age policy.  It is not something trivial and easy to do.  And identifying employment opportunities for the elderly, promoting an elder-friendly workplace, enlightened human resource practices, and looking into the establishment of informal industries and perhaps even providing micro-credit, as Miss Penny Low has suggested - we need to explore the entire spectrum. 


     We will be piloting a community platform where the elderly or homemakers can make a living selling their own products, whether it be cakes, handicrafts or services.  This has been helped recently by MND's decision last year to allow HDB homes to be registered as offices.  And in due time, I think all the Ministries are also looking at how we can enable this informal economy to thrive at the edges of what still needs to be a globally competitive economy, which is the core

Column: 2419

of our Singapore economy, and we will certainly look at providing micro-financing.

 

     Mr Wee Siew Kim spoke on the need to keep our elderly active, and I agree absolutely with him.  Keeping active can mean working.  It can also mean being a volunteer or pursuing a hobby, and I believe it is important in delaying the onset of many of the degenerative diseases which you associate with ageing.  I have heard this example of Mr Tan Kok Sing, who at age 80, led three generations of his family in skydiving from a height of 8,000 feet.  I have not even dared  to do that myself.  But I am sure, and I hope, that there are many more elderly like Mr Tan, who serves as an inspiration to all of us, both young and old alike.


     To encourage active ageing further, my Ministry runs an Active Seniors Programme (ASP).  This scheme funds up to $200,000 to community groups who want to start projects that will tap on the skills and experience of older Singaporeans.  So far, 3,000 elderly volunteers have been mobilised under the scheme.  One such project is a mentoring scheme run by a local organisation, and it is called the Retired and Senior Volunteer Programme (RSVP).  They basically run a scheme in which older Singaporeans act as mentors for latchkey kids.  In one scheme, you are addressing both the needs of the elderly and the needs of the young latchkey kids. 


     I want to encourage more of such projects, and we will set aside $200,000 out of the $1 million for the ASP fund for small-scale projects which are worth $10,000 or less.  If need be, and if there are more ideas out there, we will look for additional funds. 


     My Ministry will also organise more elderly-focused events, starting with an Inter-Generation Bonding Family Day in

Column: 2420

June 2005, and a Sports and Mind-Games Carnival in September 2005, and these are in addition to our regular Senior Citizens' Week which is held every November.


     We need to also give the elderly more reasons to be active.  Some businesses offer discounts to the elderly during the annual Senior Citizens' Week.  MCYS will build on this arrangement by introducing a Concessionary Card for seniors aged 65 and above.  Examples of these benefits could include discounts at leisure and sports facilities, shopping centres and restaurants.  Mind you, we are not asking for handouts.  It makes business sense to reach out to the elderly since they are a growing segment of our population.  But by organising it, we can optimise this and make it more attractive for the elderly to go out there to shop, to eat, or just to spend time with each other and get out of their rooms and their flats.  In addition, we will also be introducing an annual ''Elder-Friendly Award''.  This is to recognise organisations that adopt elder-friendly practices or provide elder-friendly infrastructure, services or products.

 

     Mr Davinder Singh and Dr Lily Neo brought up this very emotive issue of elder abuse.  I sympathise entirely with their views.  The issue of whether there should be automatic enhancements of penalties for people convicted of abusing the elderly is a complex one which affects the judicial system and the administration of justice, and one which I will leave it to the Minister for Law to address.  But, really, the issue is not just one of punishment.  We should be looking at preventing it from happening in the first place.  And there are still things which we can do to prevent elder abuse or at least to mitigate the effects of elder abuse.  It is worthwhile remembering that actually even today, under current legislation, the elder person who is abused can seek help and redress.  The Maintenance of Parents' Act is an avenue for the elderly to seek financial

Column: 2421

support from unfilial children.  Under the Women's Charter, although we call it the Women's Charter, its protection really extends far beyond that of just women.  Anyone in the family who suffers physical, emotional or psychological

abuse can apply for a Personal Protection Order from a Family Court.  And the Family Court can make additional orders, including requiring individuals who are involved in family violence to attend mandatory counselling.  A breach of the Protection Order constitutes a seizable offence for which one will be arrested. The Penal Code has provisions to protect the elderly against serious offences.

    I would also like to inform Dr Lily Neo that professionals and caregivers are already legally empowered and obligated to advocate on behalf of the elderly victims and help the elderly make informed decisions to protect their interests.  The caregiver can apply for a Protection Order on behalf of the elderly person.   And if there is criminal intent, the caregiver should report to the Police. The Police will investigate the matter and take appropriate action.

 

     MCYS has established a national network of agencies to ensure that there is effective early detection and intervention for both victims and perpetrators of elder abuse.  An elderly person who requires help can access services through these contact points, including Family Service Centres, the Police, hospitals and the court.  In the last two years, my Ministry has been conducting regular training sessions to help these service providers intervene appropriately.  A booklet on elder abuse and neglect has been developed to guide the service providers.

 

    Learning from our experience with child abuse, we have also piloted a programme which we call the Elder

Column: 2422

Protection Team.  This is to manage elder abuse cases.  It is a multi-disciplinary team that consists of professionals from fields like geriatrics, psychiatry, law and social work, and it is spearheaded by a VWO called Trans Centre which specialises in family violence.  The members constitute representatives from Alexandra Hospital, the Institute of Mental Health, Law Faculty of NUS, the Tsao Foundation and representatives from my Ministry.  This will play a primary role in conducting enquiries into the needs of people who are caught in this unfortunate predicament and ensuring that intervention plans are carried out. We will work with the Police and the grassroots organisations to extend our outreach and ensure that the elderly are informed of their rights.

 

    The point about empowering banks to intervene in cases of financial fraud is not so straightforward.  In the case of children, they are not adults, they do not have rights to enter into contracts and sign cheques.  In the case of the elderly, they are adults and they have legal rights. Whilst you may want to protect them, we need to do so without depriving older Singaporeans of their legal rights to enter into contracts. So there is a fine balance between protection and removing the autonomy and respect which older Singaporeans should enjoy.  Nevertheless, it is an issue which we will study in greater detail.

 

     Let me now turn very quickly to the other area on helping persons with disabilities.  We have two principles governing our approach.  First, we want disabled Singaporeans to be integrated into mainstream society.  Second, we want to maximise the potential of disabled Singaporeans.  We want them to be able to be as independent as possible.  It is in their interest and the interest of their families and society in general.  My Ministry will be raising its spending on disability-related programmes by one-third to $39 million this financial year.

 

Column: 2423

     Integration with society means giving people with disabilities more opportunities.  It means making Singapore more disabled-friendly.  An example of this also means making sure our transport infrastructure is upgraded and truly disabled-friendly.   We have taken significant steps to make Singapore more disabled-friendly.  We know that LTA has announced that by 2006, all existing MRT stations would be retrofitted and be accessible to all, including those with wheelchairs.  The pace of the Lift Upgrading Programme has been accelerated by the Ministry of National Development.  This and many other issues, for example, where my Ministry cannot do it alone, we need to work closely with MOT, MND, MOH and many other Ministries to achieve this.  But I promise we will continue to be the agitator and the champion for increasing the access of the disabled into mainstream society.

 

    I now want to touch on the Assistive Technology Fund (ATF).  This provides subsidies for assistive technology, basically computer and other high-tech equipment which can enable disabled people to overcome their primary disabilities.  Let me give you an example. A secondary three student with muscular dystrophy was one of the recent beneficiaries of this scheme. Through this scheme, he was able to obtain some assistive computer technology which helped him keep up with his school work.  By enabling him to keep up with his school work, he would be able to achieve fully and better education and, ultimately, better hope for the future. 

 

     We will be enhancing this scheme in four ways.  First, we will allow pre-school children to benefit from the ATF.  That  is because intervention at an earlier age is more significant than intervening at a later stage.  Second, we are going to increase the subsidies available for people under the Assistive Technology Fund. We will

Column: 2424

increase it by 15%.  For households earning less than $300 per person, we will increase the subsidy all the way up to 90%.  Third, we are going to make it easier for the disabled to apply for the ATF.  In the past, the disabled could only apply through six ATF assessment centres. Now, we will enable them to apply for it through any VWO or hospital.  Fourth, some disabled require specialised assessment and assistance in using these devices. The Society of the Physically Disabled, with the support of NCSS, has set up a Specialised Assistive Technology Centre to do this.  All these enhancements to the ATF will benefit an estimated 1,150 persons.

 

    Mr Sin Boon Ann called for improving the employment prospects for people with disabilities.  We focus our effort on job placement, vocational assessment and training.  As at December 2004, Bizlink, which is a non-profit organisation, has managed to place about 56% of the disabled who registered with them looking for jobs.  This is a considerable success rate if you think of the obstacles that they confront. 

 

     We are now looking at the development of more employment test beds. An employment testbed is an arrangement where a  VWO partners an employer to specially design the job so that the disabled person can do it.  Examples have been cited in this House, like restaurants, waiters, etc.  This complements the national job redesign programme that NTUC is spearheading.  In a pilot employment testbed that we started last year, the Association of Persons with Special Needs (APSN) worked with Training Master Workforce Institute to successfully place 60% of its clients in cleaning jobs.  With the success of this testbed, we are going to launch two more employment testbeds this year. We will continue to study this and see how we can optimise this further.  But I want to say that I am not in favour of making legislative

Column: 2425

changes or affirmative action to guarantee access or to improve the access of the disabled people as far as getting jobs is concerned.  There are many people who are looking for jobs. We, as a matter of principle, have resisted the temptation to rely on affirmative action and of making legislative changes because of the job and labour rigidity that will create its impact on the competitiveness of our economy.  But, more importantly, it will in the long run impair the employability of people with disabilities. They may get token jobs, but not real jobs.  It is better that we tackle the upstream - the more difficult part of changing jobs, changing mindsets and redesigning opportunities - before we resort to what seems like an obvious easy solution.

 

     Let me now touch on maximising the potential of children with disabilities.  We know that early intervention makes a difference.  Despite the Government subsidies for early intervention centres (or EIPIC), it can still cost a parent up to $400 a month to send a child to such an early intervention centre.

 

    That is why we are now going to liberalise the use of the Baby Bonus for parents who want to send such children for early intervention programmes.  This will unlock potentially up to $24,000 per child to be used for these programmes.  This will take effect from 1st July this year.  I will touch on other aspects of the Baby Bonus with the remaining time that I have. 

 

     Dr Lily Neo, Mr Sin Boon Ann and Miss Penny Low talked about caregivers.  It is a  labour of love to care for someone who is elderly, sick or disabled.  Caregivers are often under-recognised and need our support and admiration as well.  I do agree that we need to help them, provide them more information, training and emotional support.  In order to help them, we will be introducing a "Care Coordinators" pilot project at 10 eldercare facilities across the

Column: 2426

island.  A care coordinator will provide information on services that can support the caregiver, assist in referring cases, and provide counselling for the caregiver.  The care coordinator will also arrange for training and support programmes to enhance the welfare of caregivers.  If this pilot works, we will extend it to more centres.

 

     I am also happy to report that nine days ago, on 1st March, we set up a Disability Information and Resource Centre (DIRC). This is a one-stop centre which will provide information and guidance to all those who need help in looking after the disabled. It will be a hotline service and it also provides face-to-face consultation services as well as web and electronic access. We hope it will  ease the burden on caregivers by helping with referrals to the most appropriate agencies - the hospitals, VWOs, CDCs and other organisations which can help the people under their care.

 

     To raise the awareness of the importance of home-based caregiving and to publicise other forms of caregiver support, my Ministry will earmark an annual budget of $400,000 to fund sustained public education programmes for caregivers.

 

     Sir, let me just touch on families.  All of us cherish our families. They are our greatest source of joy, friendship, emotional satisfaction and moral support.  Our families mould us, define our values, and ultimately give our lives meaning.  But family life and work all clamour for our attention. All of us need to constantly remind ourselves as to what is truly important in our lives.  

 

    As we try to support families at a practical level, the Government has already taken some concrete measures. The five-day work week was introduced in the civil service. We provided childcare leave, additional maternity leave as well

Column: 2427

as funding for initiatives that promote work-life balance in companies.

 

     Financial support, in the form of  Baby Bonus, is part of the pro-family package.  Mr Sin Boon Ann asked whether this money has resulted in any improvement in the birth rates. Sir, I really do not want to count the chickens - or the babies - before they are hatched.  But I do want to assure Mr Sin that we are working with the people and the private sector to actively promote strong family bonds.  We conduct marriage support and enrichment programmes, parent-child bonding initiatives as well as training on parenting skills and inter-generational bonding activities.  We have initiatives like the School Family Education and the "School Social Work to Empower Pupils to Utilise their Potential" programme (or STEP-UP), which have been set up in 144 schools, to help parents upgrade their parenting skills while equipping their children with life skills.  That said, a strong family only works as an act of will and commitment. The foundation for a family ultimately must be love, respect and communication.  The Government and the community can only provide a supporting environment.  We cannot make it happen.

     On the effectiveness of the Baby Bonus and other monetary schemes, I want to reiterate this point: the decision to have a baby must be a personal decision made by the two people involved, and not by the Government.  Our financial support is not an incentive to "buy" more babies.  It is your decision, but we will support you. 

 

     We know that the cost of raising a child is a key consideration for many couples.  So the Baby Bonus was conceived, unintended, as a way to help defray the costs of raising children.  The Baby Bonus

Column: 2428

has a two-tier grant structure.  The first-tier is a direct cash gift of $3,000 each for the first and second child, and $6,000 each for the third and fourth child.  The second-tier is a co-savings component over six years where Government matches the parents' contributions into the child's saving account, dollar for dollar, up to a maximum amount.  

 

     We have received much feedback over the last few months asking that this scheme be made more flexible.  We have made it more flexible in two ways.  First, we allow the co-savings to be used to pay the fees of not only MCYS-licensed childcare centres and MOE-registered kindergartens, but we will now allow the Baby Bonus co-savings to be used to purchase MediShield or MediShield-equivalent healthcare insurance for their children from December 2005.  This will give parents greater peace of mind over unexpected medical bills, should their children suffer from prolonged medical problems.

 

     We will also be more flexible in the way we match the parents' savings.  Some parents miss out on the contributions every year because they say, "Well, I am unemployed", or "I have cash flow problem and I cannot contribute to it now.".  Others say, "I want to put all the money in upfront, early.".  We have increased the flexibility so that parents can “top up�? the co-savings up to a maximum of $6,000 for the second child and $12,000 each for the third and fourth child, any time within the six-year period, and we will match it.  With this flexibility, I would encourage all families to take advantage of the savings scheme and set aside money for their children's long-term future. 

 

     We will also make it more convenient for parents to benefit from the Baby Bonus Scheme.  In the past, even right now, parents have to fill in an application form for the Baby Bonus cash gift, then

Column: 2429

they have to make a trip down to a POSB branch to open a co-savings account.  We will now move towards a one-stop, one-form, opt-out system, for both the cash gift and the Baby Bonus co-savings, all at the point when you register your child.  We want to make it convenient and we want all of you to open this account, and not make it difficult and lechey for you to do so.  Our target is to do this by December 2005.  But, if I can accelerate it, I will do so.

 

     Adoption leave - we introduced this last year as part of our pro-family package to allow adoptive mothers to care for their newborns, aged 6 months and below.  Adoptive mothers are eligible for Adoption leave of up to four weeks if their employers voluntarily grant it.  The leave would be granted when the adoption was completed.  The only problem was that usually it took more than six months for the adoption process to be completed and, therefore, de facto, hardly anyone could enjoy the leave. 

 

     Again, in response to feedback, we have changed the system.  We will now allow adoptive mothers to take their Adoption leave at a much earlier point in the adoption process.  With this change, adoptive mothers can take leave at the point when the Court appoints MCYS as Guardian-Ad-Litem, or, in the case of a foreign adoption, when the child has received a dependant's pass.  This will mean that the leave will start fairly soon after the child is physically with the adoptive family.  I believe this is important, especially for the mother to look after the adoptive newborn, and to bond with the newborn.

 

     Families, being the first line of support, are just one of the “Many Helping Hands�? holding up our social safety net.  Other major partners are the people sector and Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs).  They play a vital role, as I have said earlier, in delivering

Column: 2430

services on the ground.  They feel, know and understand the problems faced by the less fortunate in our society. 

 

     We need our VWOs to be professional and innovative.  Many of them, in fact, all of them, rely on the public for their funds.  We want to encourage them not only to economise on the way they spend the money, but also, as Miss Penny Low has suggested, to look for more sustainable models to generate revenue.  And that is where this issue of social enterprise comes in.

 

     Social enterprise is basically a business, but a business with a social mission.  Profits or surpluses are not generated for the sake of shareholders but are used to further a social objective.   I believe if more VWOs try the social enterprise model, they would have a more sustainable and, hopefully, more secure source of funding in the future.  It is also another way for VWOs to help create jobs for their target recipients of their assistance.  

 

     So, to support social enterprises, MCYS has already set up the Social Enterprise Fund a year and a half ago.  It provides seed capital for these social enterprises and, to-date, we have awarded about $3.6 million to support 38 projects.  Of these, 31 have already started operations.  We have linked them up with more established businessmen and people with more experience in business.  I want to make an appeal here for successful Singaporeans with business experience to lend their expertise, business contacts and acumen to these fledgling social enterprises. 

 

     These are just infant steps.  It is only just the beginning.  There have been many, many more suggestions coming from MPs and people on the ground.  I want to encourage all the people involved

Column: 2431

in this to share best practices, to network and to be more innovative in coming up with new programmes.  We will look into all these suggestions as we nurture this sector.

     Mr Sin Boon Ann: Sir, just a point of clarification.  When I mentioned about legislation to facilitate employment for the elderly and the disabled, I was not referring to any form of  affirmative action.  What I was referring to was the introduction of legislation to make it an offence to discriminate, and this is really quite different from reserving jobs for the elderly, which I understand bucks against

Column: 2432

the trends of the market forces and may not be in our economic interests.

 

     There are many countries in the West that have adopted such legislation.  I know that one of the difficulties has to do with finding the basis for prosecuting a prospective employer on the basis of discrimination.  But I suppose such legislation is not intended to bring about enforcement or prosecution, but to change the mindset and to signal a change on the part of prospective employers that there is a framework out there which compels them to take into account fairness and openness when seriously considering applications from such disabled or elderly persons.

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: I sympathise with the intent behind the Member's proposal, but I remain unconvinced that legislation is the most effective way of changing mindsets.  I think we have to work on persuasion, education and demonstrating by social pressure that it is wrong to discriminate.  But the issue of discrimination goes beyond just the disabled and elderly.  There are other cases like gender, ethnic or religious.  So there are many issues when we talk about discrimination.  So far, as a matter of policy, we have avoided the temptation to legislate against discrimination, not that we feel that it is not important, but the difficulties in enforcement and implementation have led us to hesitate before going down that road.  But it is certainly something which you, and many of us, are concerned with, and we will continue to study this.  I am not willing to move down that road yet.

     Dr Lily Neo: Mr Chairman, earlier on, the Minister said that he would leave the law on elderly abuse to the Ministry of Law.  Can I ask him: surely, this provision must be initiated by his Ministry, rather than just leaving it to the Ministry of Law?

 

Column: 2433

     Could I ask the Minister whether he would consider setting up a Central Registry since he is streamlining all the different schemes of assistance and employing more social workers to look into this group that is most in need?

     Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: The proposal from Mr Davinder Singh was for automatic enhancement of penalties for people who have been convicted of elder abuse.  He used the precedent set by changes which we made to the law with respect to domestic maids.  Again, I will reiterate that I share the sentiment behind it, but I want this House to be aware that every time you legislate so-called automatic enhancements of penalties, or you make mandatory penalties in place, you are actually tying the hands and the discretion of our courts and you are making our legal system less flexible.  So there are both pros and cons to this proposal.  I have said that I am not convinced that this is the road yet.  But looking at what needs to be done to prevent elder abuse, what we need to do to ensure early detection of elder abuse, and what we need to do to support victims of elder abuse have led me to the conclusion that there is a lot more work to be done upstream, rather than opting for this apparently easy quick-fix. 

 

     Now, I grant you that it does send a signal but, again, the problem is with implementation and the fact that you are tying the hands and the discretion of the judges.  The prosecutors can, and do, ask for deterrent sentences.  And that is why I said it is more an issue of the administration of justice, rather than a policy of how important elder abuse is to our society.  Nevertheless, it is still something which I would study together with my colleague, the Minister for Law.

 

    The second question on social register.  We need to set up a central registry of all people receiving help.  Similarly, we
